--- title: "Day 1A" format: html: css: ../styles.css --- ![](../img/teaching_2780E3.svg){.hero} We will begin with an overview of the workshop, an introduction to R and RStudio, and the basics of programming. The latter will cover objects, naming, and functions. ## Slides [Click here to view the slides in their own window.](./Slides/01A_Slides.html) ## Practice ### Question 1. Read what the user wanted to do and look at the command they sent to R. Fix the errors in the commands and calculate the answers. a) I want to add 20 and 0.2 and divide that sum by 4.1. But I get an error when I try:
`[20 + .2] \ 4.1` b) I want to multiply 6 by the sum of 2 and 1,300. But I get an error when I try:
`6 x (2 + 1,300)`

Click here for the answer key
**Answer (a)** Change the brackets `[]` to parentheses `()` because parentheses `()` are the order of operations operator in R. Also, change the backslash `\` to a forward slash `/` because forward slash `/` is the division operator in R. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (20 + .2) / 4.1 #> [1] 4.926829 ``` ::: **Answer (b)** Change the `x` to an asterisk `*` because asterisk `*` is the multiplication operator in R. Also, remove the comma `,` from `1,300` because R doesn't use commas to delimit digits in large numbers. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 6 * (2 + 1300) #> [1] 7812 ``` :::

--- ### Question 2 Which of the following commands do you think will create an error in R? Why? a) `score@T1 <- 3.2` b) `score_at_T1 <- 3.2` c) `score at T1 <- 3.2` d) `1_score <- 3.2` e) `ScoreAtTime1 <- 3.2` Make your best guesses just by looking at the commands and then check your guesses by running the commands in R.

Click here for the answer key > The following commands will create an error in R: **a** (`@` is not allowed in an object name), **c** (spaces are not allowed in an object name), and **d** (the first character in an object name cannot be a number).

--- ### Question 3 a) Use the `cos()` function to calculate the cosine of 3 and assign it to a variable called `y`. Print the value of `y` to the console. b) Use a function to round `y` to the nearest whole number. c) Use a function to round `y` to two decimal places.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Part (a) y <- cos(3) y ## [1] -0.9899925 # Part (b) round(y) ## [1] -1 # Part (c) round(y, digits = 2) ## [1] -0.99 ``` :::

--- ### Question 4 What do you expect the result to be for the following commands? a) `sqrt(4 + 5)` b) `sqrt(4) + 5` Make your best guesses just by looking at the commands and then check your guesses by running the commands in R.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Part (a): Add then square root, same as sqrt(9) sqrt(4 + 5) ## [1] 3 # Part (b): Square root then add, same as 2 + 5 sqrt(4) + 5 ## [1] 7 ``` :::

## Readings - ["Chapter 3: Workflow - Basics"](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/workflow-basics.html) from R4DS (2E) - ["Chapter 7: Workflow - Scripts and Projects"](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/workflow-scripts.html) from R4DS (2E) ## Fun Stuff "The Literal Genie" - What it feels like to talk to R sometimes {{< video https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/58l7ZqoU0a0 >}}
